titleStmt.title: Stella to the Dean on his Birthday

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: November 30 1722
St Patricks Dean, your Countrys pride
My early and my only guide,
<L>et me among the rest attend,
<You>r Pupil, and your humble friend,
<To> celebrate in femal strains

<The day> that pay'd your Mothers pains,damage <to ta>ke <thi>s tribute duedamage to <y>ou damagedamage <t>o call me fair<.>damage<rpos'd> y<our> timely caredamage ear<ly taught> me to despisedamage<e ogling> of a Coxcombs eyesdamage<h>ow'd where my Iudgment was misplac't
<R>efin'd my fancy and my tast<:>Behold that beauty just decay'ddamage<v>oking art to natures ayddamagesook by her admiring traindamage <sp>reads her tatter'd Nets in Vain
Short was her part upon the stage
Went smoothly on for half a Page
Her Bloom was gone, she wanted art
As the Scene chang'd to change her part
She whom no Lover could resist
Before the Second act was hist
Such is the fate of femal race
With no endowment but a face
Before the thirty'th year of Life
A Maid forlorn, or hated wife.
Stella to you her Tutor owes
That she hath ne'er resembled those
Nor was a burthen to mankind
With half her course of years behind
You taught how I might youth prolong
By knowing what was right and wrong
How from the heart to bring supplyes
Of Luster to my fading Eyes
How soon a beauteous mind repairs
The loss of chang'd or falling hairs
How wit and virtue from within
Sends out a smoothness ore the skin
your Lectures could my fancy fix
And I can please at thirty Six
The sight of Chloe at fifteen
Coquetting gives not me the spleen
The Idol now of every fool
Till age shall make thier passions cool
<Then> tumbling down times steepy hill
<Whil>e Stella holds her Station stilldamage <your> precepts into Lawsdamageedeem <t>he Wdamageens ruin'd cause.damage empire to our sexdamage<at> men may bow their rebell necks<.>
<Long> be the day that gave you birth
<S>acred to friendship, Wit, and Mirth;
Late dying may you cast a shred
Of your rich Mantle o'er my head
To bear with dignity my Sorrow
One Day alone, then dye to morrow.737-328H
